title: National Heritage Conservation Commission (Ng’wena Village) (National Monument) (Declaration) Order, 2023
content:
17th August, 2023 Statutory Instruments 193
GOVERNMENT OF ZAMBIA
STATUTORY INSTRUMENT NO. 27 of 2023
The National Heritage Conservation Commission Act
(Laws, Volume 12, Cap 173)
The National Heritage Conservation Commission
(Ng’wena Village) (National Monument) (Declaration)
Order, 2023
IN EXERCISE of the powers contained in section 27 of the National
Heritage Conservation Commission Act, the following Order is
made:
1. This Order may be cited as the National Heritage Title
Conservation Commission (Ng’wena Village) (National Monument)
(Declaration) Order, 2023.
2. The heritage described in the Schedule is declared a national Declaration
monument. of national
monument
Copies of this Statutory Instrument can be obtained from the Government Printer,
P.O. Box 30136, 10101 Lusaka. Price K4.00 each.
194 Statutory Instruments 17th August, 2023
SCHEDULE
(Paragraph 2)
NG’WENA VILLAGE
LOCATION
The site is located at 09° 59’ 22’’ S, 31° 41’ 00’’ E (UTM: 0355699, 8895452) in Mungwi
District of Northern Province, in Chitimukulu Area, the Headquarters of the Bemba Kingdoms of
Northern and Muchinga Provinces.
The site is defined by the circular 17th - 19th Century war trenches located to the north of the
confluence of the Milando and Kalungu Rivers, with the riverine areas characterised by dambos
while the central area is composed of secondary miombo woodlands.
STATEMENT OF SIGNIFICANCE
The circular 17th - 19th Century war trenches characterise the centre of the old Ng’wena
Village, the founding village of Ulubemba. The village, named after the clan totem (crocodile) of
the Chitimukulu Royals, marked the end of the Bemba migration from the Congo Basin.
From Ng’wena Village and through conquest of surrounding ethnic groups, Ulubemba grew to
forty-three semi-autonomous kingdoms. The colonial Government amalgamated the forty-three
Bemba kingdoms into eighteen native reserves which were subsequently named chiefdoms.
The mid-18th Century Bemba-Ngoni wars at Ng’wena Village birthed the peace-preserving
Bemba-Ngoni tribal cousinship known by the Bemba people as Bunungwe and by Ngoni people
as Chimbuya.
Every year in August, all the Bemba Kingdoms gather at the centre of the Ng’wena Village for
Ukusefya pa Ng’wena Ceremony which means, festivities at the old Ng’wena Village. Through
the ceremony, Bemba people celebrate and re-enact their founding history and pay homage to the
Chitimukulu, the ritualistic and political head of the present-day Bemba Kingdom.
BOUNDARY DESCRIPTION
The described area measuring approximately 707 hectares, is shown on a plan marked red, and
signed by the Surveyor-General and deposited in the office of the Surveyor-General and the
National Heritage Conservation Commission, Lusaka.
R. SIKUMBA,
LUSAKA Minister of Tourism
11th August, 2023
[MTA.13/7/1]
